title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: At Gattonside is Gattonside House (General Duncan).

title: Black's picturesque tourist of Scotland.
snippet: The village of Gattonside, with its numerous orchards, on the other side of the Tweed, is connected with Melrose by a chain bridge.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Mr. Stuart, the grandnephew  of my dear friend Lady Louisa, also dined with us, together with the Lyons from Gattonside, and the day passed over in hospitality and social happiness.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: We dined at Gattonside with Mr. Bainbridge, who kindly presented me with six bottles of super-excellent Jamaica rum, and with a manuscript collection of poetry, said to be Swift's handwriting, which it resembles.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Mr. Stuart, the grand-nephew of my dear friend Lady Louisa, also dined with us, together with the Lyons from Gattonside, and the day passed over in hospitality and social happiness.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Here is a vile day downright rain, which disconcerts an inroad of bairns from Gattonside, and, of course, annihilates a part of the stock of human happiness.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: I wrote as hard to-day as need be, finished my neat eight pages, and, notwithstanding, drove out and visited at Gattonside.

title: The journal of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Dined at Chiefswood with Captain and Mrs. Hamilton, Lady Lucy Whitmore, their guest, and neighbours from Gattonside and Huntly Burn.

title: A Tour in Tartan-Land
author: Bede, Cuthbert
snippet: It says that the iconoclast was aperson of tbe name of Thomson, of Gattonside, who wasemployed for the purpose of demolishing* the images;but that, when he was in the act of striking at thisfigure of the infant Christ, he himself was struck by astone so forcibly on his arm, that he never afterwardsregained the use of it; and that, in consequence of

title: A Tour in Tartan-Land
author: Bede, Cuthbert
snippet: He placed hiscannon at Gattonside, on the farther side of the Tweed,and pounded away at the Abbey with a relentless heart,smashing its mullioned windows, and tumbling over itsbattlements and pinnacles, until, as it is said, ' he madeit almost a complete ruin.'
